Section.Description: A chemical formula is a way of expressing information about the proportions of atoms that constitute a particular chemical compound, using a single line of chemical element symbols and numbers. PubChem uses the Hill system, whereby the number of carbon atoms in a molecule is indicated first, the number of hydrogen atoms second, and then the number of all other chemical elements in alphabetical order. When the formula contains no carbon, all the elements, including hydrogen, are listed alphabetically. Sources other than PubChem may include a variant of the formula that is more structural or natural to chemists, for example, H2SO4 for sulfuric acid, rather than the Hill version H2O4S.

Section.Description: Isotope atom count is the number of isotopes that are not most abundant for the corresponding chemical elements. The "defined atom stereocenter count" is the number of atom stereocenters whose configurations are specifically defined.

StringWithMarkup.String: An investigation of the metabolism of the weak carcinogen, benz(a)anthracene, was compared to that of a group of noncarcinogenic hydrocarbons including benzo(e)pyrene, pyrene, phenanthrene, coronene, triphenylene, and perylene. Male Sprague-Dawley rats were administered sc 0.4 uM doses of these polynuclear aromatic hydrocarbons. Results from HPLC and MS demonstrated that benz(a)anthracene was observed to undergo bioalkylation and biooxidation reactions in rat sc tissue. The other compounds tested did not demonstrate detectable bioalkylation reactions in vivo. These results were consistent with the carcinogenic activity of benz(a)anthracene and the noncarcinogenic potential of the other compounds examined. The data indicated that the metabolic activation of nonfunctional carcinogenic aromatic hydrocarbons was due to the introduction of an alkyl group in a highly reactive mesoanthracenic center in the molecule. Further investigation is necessary to determine whether the bioalkylation reaction can be used as a general probe for the carcinogenic activity of nonfunctional polynuclear aromatic hydrocarbons.

StringWithMarkup.String: PAHs are a group of chemicals that are formed during the incomplete burning of coal, oil, gas, wood, garbage, or other organic substances, such as tobacco and charbroiled meat. There are more than 100 different PAHs. PAHs generally occur as complex mixtures (for example, as part of combustion products such as soot), not as single compounds. PAHs usually occur naturally, but they can be manufactured as individual compounds for research purposes; however, not as the mixtures found in combustion products. ... Others are contained in asphalt used in road construction. They can also be found in substances such as crude oil, coal, coal tar pitch, creosote, and roofing tar. They are found throughout the environment in the air, water, and soil. They can occur in the air, either attached to dust particles or as solids in soil or sediment. /Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons/

Section.Description: Disposal methods or procedures for this chemical or hazardous waste containing it.

StringWithMarkup.String: SRP: Recycle any unused portion of the material for its approved use or return it to the manufacturer or supplier. Ultimate disposal of the chemical must consider: the material's impact on air quality; potential migration in air, soil or water; effects on animal, aquatic and plant life; and conformance with environmental and public health regulations. If it is possible or reasonable use an alternative chemical product with less inherent propensity for occupational harm/injury/toxicity or environmental contamination.

SRP: Wastewater from contaminant suppression, cleaning of protective clothing/equipment, or contaminated sites should be contained and evaluated for subject chemical or decomposition product concentrations. Concentrations shall be lower than applicable environmental discharge or disposal criteria. Alternatively, pretreatment and/or discharge to a permitted wastewater treatment facility is acceptable only after review by the governing authority and  assurance that "pass through" violations will not occur. Due consideration shall be given to  remediation worker exposure (inhalation, dermal and ingestion) as well as fate during treatment, transfer and disposal. If it is not practicable to manage the chemical in this fashion, it must be evaluated in accordance with EPA 40 CFR Part 261, specifically Subpart B, in order to determine the appropriate local, state and federal requirements for disposal.

Section.Description: The Immediately Dangerous to Life or Health air concentration values (IDLH values) characterize high-risk exposure concentrations and conditions and are used as a component of respirator selection criteria.  IDLH values are established (1) to ensure that the worker can escape from a given contaminated environment in the event of failure of the respiratory protection equipment and (2) to indicate a maximum level above which only a highly reliable breathing apparatus, providing maximum worker protection, is permitted.

Section.Description: The threshold limit value (TLV) of a chemical is an airborne concentration at which a worker can be exposed day after day for a working lifetime without adverse effect.  There are three types of TLVs for chemicals. [1] Threshold limit value - time-weighted average (TLV-TWA): average exposure on the basis of a 8h/day, 40h/week work schedule. [2] Threshold limit value - short-term exposure limit (TLV-STEL): a 15-minute TWA exposure that should not be exceeded at any time during a workday, even if the 8-hour TWA is within the TLV-TWA. [3] Threshold limit value - ceiling limit (TLV-C): absolute exposure limit that should not be exceeded at any time. TLVs are developed by the American Conference of Governmental Industrial Hygienist.  While TLVs are widely accepted occupational exposure limits, they are not standards enforced by the U.S. Government.

Reference: American Conference of Governmental Industrial Hygienists TLVs and BEIs. Threshold Limit Values for Chemical Substances and Physical Agents and Biological Exposure Indices. Cincinnati, OH 2016, p. 22

These lists are to be used by EPA and States to develop the Effluent Guidelines regulations and ensure water quality criteria and standards.

StringWithMarkup.String: For the maximum protection of human health from the potential carcinogenic effects of exposure to polynuclear aromatic hydrocarbons through ingestion of contaminated water and contaminated aquatic organisms, the ambient water concentration should be zero,  based on the nonthreshold assumption for this chemical. However, zero level may not be attainable at the present time. Therefore, the levels which may result in incremental increase of cancer risk over the lifetime are estimated at 1X10-5, 1X10-6, and 1X10-7. The corresponding recommended criteria are 28.0 ng/L, 2.8 ng/L, and 0.28 ng/L, respectively. If these estimates are made for consumption of aquatic organisms only, excluding consumption of water, the levels are 311.0 ng/L, 31.1 ng/L, and 3.11 ng/L, respectively. /Polynuclear aromatic hydrocarbons/.

StringWithMarkup.String: IDENTIFICATION AND USE: Perylene forms yellow to colorless crystals. It is used in the manufacture of organic semiconductors. Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are a group of chemicals that are formed during the incomplete burning of coal, oil, gas, wood, garbage, or other organic substances, such as tobacco and charbroiled meat. HUMAN EXPOSURE AND TOXICITY: Perylene did not induce mutations in cultured human lymphoblastoid cells. Perylene exerted a cytotoxic effect on human keratinocytes in vitro. The agent is not classifiable as to its carcinogenicity to humans. ANIMAL STUDIES: Perylene dermal applications, or i.p. injections did not induce tumors in mice. Benzo(a)pyrene hydroxylase activity of the rat placenta can be induced by perylene. ECOTOXICITY STUDIES: Perylene did not induce 7-ethoxyresorufin-o-deethylase (EROD) activity in the rainbow trout liver cells.

StringWithMarkup.String: A group of 20 female ICR/Ha Swiss mice, six to eight weeks of age, received a single dose of 800 ug perylene (purified by recrystallization) in 200 uL benzene applied on the clipped dorsal skin. No skin tumor was seen after 58-60 weeks of observation. In a second experiment, the same dose of perylene was administered to 20 female ICR/Ha mice; two weeks later the animals received thrice-weekly applications of 2.5 ug 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate in 0.1 mL acetone for the duration of the experiment (58-60 weeks). A total of three skin papillomas were observed in three animals; in the 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate control group, one mouse developed two papillomas ... .

Reference: Bahri R et al; J Toxicol Environ Health A 73 (8): 552-64 (2010)

StringWithMarkup.String: The cytotoxic effects of two polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAH) (1-methyplyrene and perylene) were investigated on human skin keratinocytes. Normal human keratinocytes were cultured in the presence of various concentrations of 1-methylpyrene and perylene either alone or in combination. Following incubation, keratinocyte adhesion, viability, proliferation, colony-forming efficiency, and apoptosis/necrosis level were examined. The effects of PAH on wound healing were also determined in vitro using a scrape-wound healing assay on epidermis-like tissue. In addition, the inflammatory cell response to PAH insult was examined through interleukin-1 (IL-1) alpha and interleukin-6 (IL-6) secretion. Each individual PAH significantly decreased keratinocyte adhesion and viability in a concentration-dependent manner, which was associated with a reduced ability of keratinocytes to proliferate and form colonies. When PAH were combined, a greater effect on keratinocyte adhesion, viability, and proliferation was noted. Decreased cell proliferation/colony-forming efficiency was accompanied by increased cell apoptosis following incubation with either PAH. This effect was enhanced by the inhibitory influence on keratinocyte migration, as assessed by culture scratching. Each PAH also exerted a significant effect on keratinocyte immune functions by modulating the secretion of inflammatory mediators. Indeed, 1-methylpyrene or perylene, individually or when combined, significantly upregulated IL-1alpha and IL-6 secretion. This effect was greater and was concentration dependent when the PAH combination was used. Overall results indicate that 1-methylpyrene and perylene exerted a cytotoxic effect on human keratinocytes. ...

Section.Description: Information on antidote and emergency treatment when exposed to this chemical.  The information here is from the Hazardous Substances Data Bank (HSDB).

Reference: Currance, P.L. Clements, B., Bronstein, A.C. (Eds).; Emergency Care For Hazardous Materials Exposure. 3rd revised edition, Elsevier Mosby, St. Louis, MO 2007, p. 209

StringWithMarkup.String: /SRP:/ Immediate First Aid: Ensure that adequate decontamination has been carried out. If patient is not breathing, start artificial respiration, preferably with a demand-valve resuscitator, bag-valve-mask device, or pocket mask, as trained. Perform CPR if necessary. Immediately flush contaminated eyes with gently flowing water. Do not induce vomiting. If vomiting occurs, lean patient forward or place on left side (head-down position, if possible) to maintain an open airway and prevent aspiration. Keep patient quiet and maintain normal body temperature. Obtain medical attention. /Aromatic hydrocarbons and related compounds/

Reference: Currance, P.L. Clements, B., Bronstein, A.C. (Eds).; Emergency Care For Hazardous Materials Exposure. 3rd revised edition, Elsevier Mosby, St. Louis, MO 2007, p. 209-10

StringWithMarkup.String: /SRP:/ Basic treatment: Establish a patent airway (oropharyngeal or nasopharyngeal airway, if needed). Suction if necessary. Watch for signs of respiratory insufficiency and assist ventilations if necessary. Administer oxygen by nonrebreather mask at 10 to 15 L/min. Monitor for pulmonary edema and treat if necessary ... . Monitor for shock and treat if necessary ... . Anticipate seizures and treat if necessary. ... For eye contamination, flush eyes immediately with water. Irrigate each eye continuously with 0.9% saline (NS) during transport ... . Do not use emetics. For ingestion, rinse mouth and administer 5 mL/kg up to 200 L of water for dilution if the patient can swallow, has a strong gag reflex, and does not drool. Administer activated charcoal ... . /Aromatic hydrocarbons and related compounds/

Reference: Currance, P.L. Clements, B., Bronstein, A.C. (Eds).; Emergency Care For Hazardous Materials Exposure. 3rd revised edition, Elsevier Mosby, St. Louis, MO 2007, p. 210

StringWithMarkup.String: /SRP:/ Advanced treatment: Consider orotracheal or nasotracheal intubation for airway control in the patient who is unconscious, has severe pulmonary edema, or is in severe respiratory distress. Positive-pressure ventilation techniques with a bag-valve-mask device may be beneficial. Consider drug therapy for pulmonary edema ... . Consider administering a beta agonist such as albuterol for severe bronchospasm ... . Monitor cardiac rhythm and treat arrhythmias if necessary ... . Start IV administration of D5W TKO /SRP: "To keep open", minimal flow rate/. Use 0.9% saline (NS) or lactated Ringer's (LR) if signs of hypovolemia are present. For hypotension with signs of hypovolemia, administer fluid cautiously. Watch for signs of fluid overload ... . Treat seizures with diazepam (Valium) or lorazepam (Ativan) ... . Use proparacaine hydrochloride to assist eye irrigation ... . /Aromatics hydrocarbons and related compounds/

StringWithMarkup.String: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Chronic Exposure or Carcinogenicity/ Groups of 20 female Crl/CD-1 (ICR)Br mice [age unspecified] received a total of 10 dermal applications of 0 or 100 ug perylene (purity >99% by HPLC) in 100 uL acetone on alternate days. Ten days after the last application, all mice received thrice weekly dermal applications of 2.5 ug TPA for 25 weeks. At the end of the treatment period, the incidence of skin tumors (5%) in mice treated with perylene (0.1 tumors/ mouse) did not differ from that in the control mice (0.1 tumors/mouse).

StringWithMarkup.String: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Chronic Exposure or Carcinogenicity/ A group of 20 female ICR/Ha Swiss mice, six to eight weeks of age, received 60 uL of a 0.15% solution of perylene (purified by recrystalization) in decalin applied twice weekly to the interscapular area for 82 weeks or until the mouse died or developed a tumor. At 25 weeks, 16 mice were still alive, and no skin tumor developed. In a second experiment, 20 male mice were treated with 0.15% perylene dissolved in a vehicle obtained by addition to decalin:n-dodecane (1:1 v/v); one papilloma, which regressed, was observed in 15 animals surviving more than 52 weeks. In 13 animals alive at 52 weeks and treated with the vehicle only, two papillomas occurred ... . (The Working Group noted that n-dodecane has been shown to have a cocarcinogenic effect when administered simultaneously with several polynuclear hydrocarbons).

Section.Description: This section provides information to evaluate the environmental impact of the chemical if it were released to the environment. The information may include data from toxicity tests performed on aquatic and/or terrestrial organisms, where available (e.g., acute or chronic aquatic toxicity data for fish, algae, and crustaceans; toxicity data on birds, bees, and plants).  This section also includes information on whether there is a potential for the chemical to persist or degrade in the environment either through biodegradation or other processes (such as oxidation or hydrolysis) as well as the concentration or amount of the chemical found in the environment (e.g., in plants, animals as well as in the atmosphere or water).
Excerpts about ecotoxicity of this compound, extracted from authoritative documents, such as journal articles, government reports, and reference books.

Reference: Bols NC et al; Ecotoxicol Environ Saf 44 (1): 118-28 (1999)

StringWithMarkup.String: /AQUATIC SPECIES/ Along with 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin (TCDD), 24 unsubstituted polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) were evaluated for their ability to induce 7-ethoxyresorufin-o-deethylase (EROD) activity in the rainbow trout liver cell line RTL-W1. When the duration and cell density of exposure were increased, the EC(50) for EROD induction was relatively constant for TCDD, but increased for PAHs. Regardless of exposure conditions, EROD activity was not induced by 9 PAHs: naphthalene, phenanthrene, anthracene, pyrene, perylene, acenaphthylene, acenaphthene, fluorene, and fluoranthene. Two PAHs, benzo[g,h,i]perylene and coronene, induced EROD activity inconsistently. The remaining 13 PAHs consistently induced EROD activity. The EC(50)s for induction exhibited approximately a 110-fold range. The order of potency, from most to least potent, was benzo[k]fluoranthene, dibenzo[a,i]pyrene, dibenzo [a,h]anthracene, benzo[a]pyrene, indeno[1,2,3-cd]pyrene, benzo [b]fluoranthene, pentacene, benzo[b]anthracene, benzo[b] fluorene, chrysene, benzo[a]anthracene, benzo[e]pyrene, and triphenylene. When the induction potency was expressed relative to TCDD, the toxic equivalency factors (TEFs) ranged from 0.001 to 0.00001. When expressed relative to benzo[a]pyrene, the TEFs ranged from 3.44 to 0.03.

Reference: Cunha A et al; Ecotoxicology 15 (2): 171-85 (2006)

StringWithMarkup.String: /AQUATIC SPECIES/ ... The objectives of this work were: (1) to follow the toxicity of high concentrations of perylene (110 mg/L) on benthic bacteria and macrofauna (amphipod Corophium multisetosum); (2) to determine the effects of a low load of perylene(2 ug/L) on the metabolism of suspended bacteriobenthos after 9-day exposure, mimicking the effects of tidal erosion; (3) to contrast the effects of this low perylene load on the particle-free bacterioplankton and on the suspended and particle-adhered bacteriobenthos. No impact was detected in bacterial abundance exposed to 110 mg perylene/L for 9 days. This concentration of perylene evoked no acute effects in C. multisetosum but, chronic toxicity assays revealed statistically significant negative effects on survival, growth and number of pregnant females. The bacterioplankton and the suspended bacteriobenthos, exposed to 2 ug perylene/L during 2 weeks, responded with altered profiles of activity when compared to the control suspension. These values ranged, respectively, for bacterial biomass production from 134 to 210 and from 24 to 184 ug C/L/hr, for aminopeptidase from 1824 to 11,127 and from 1464 to 15,488 nmol/L/hr, and for beta-glucosidase from 87 to 400 and from 57 to 1278 nmol/L/hr. The rate of oxygen consumption in the perylene-exposed suspension (0.04-2.85 mmol O2/kg dw sed/hr) exhibited a clearly distinct profile in relation to the control (0.57-1.60 mmol O2/kg dw sed/hr). The overall reactivity of the bacteriobenthos to perylene was interpreted as the result of toxic pressure followed by evolution of a diverse bacterial community.

Reference: Fent K, Batscher R; Environ Toxicol Chem 19 (8): 2047-58 (2000)

StringWithMarkup.String: /AQUATIC SPECIES/ The relative CYP1A induction potencies, determined as ethoxyresorufin-O-deethylase (EROD) activity, and the cytotoxicities of 19 compounds with one to six benzene rings, mixtures of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), and contaminated landfill leachates have been determined in the permanent fish hepatoma cell line PLHC-1. No CYP1A induction was observed with benzene, naphthalene, anthracene, acenaphthene, benzo[g,h,i]perylene, and fluorene and low induction was found with fluoranthene and phenanthrene. All other PAHs with three and more benzene rings led to a concentration-related induction of CYP1A, with rebound decreases at high concentrations resulting in bell-shaped concentration-activity curves. Fish-related induction equivalency factors (IEFs) were estimated for all PAHs on the basis of EC50 values of their EROD activities and are reported here for the first time. The following order of decreasing IEFs was found: dibenz[a,h]anthracene > dibenzo[a,i]pyrene > benzo[k]fluoranthene > 3-methylcholanthrene > benzo[a]pyrene > benzo[e]pyrene > chrysene > 7,12-dimethylbenz[a]anthracene > perylene > benz[a]anthracene > pyrene. In contrast to the EROD activity, the immunodetectable protein content determined by ELISA showed a concentration-dependent increase. The interaction of PAHs in mixtures of up to eight individual compounds was additive based on their EROD activities. In landfill leachates, determined induction equivalents (IEQ) were significantly higher than calculated IEQs based on analytical measurements, which indicates additional unknown inducing compounds present in leachates. This study shows that the PLHC-1 cell in vitro system serves as an integrative bioanalytical tool in the ecotoxicological evaluation of aquatic environmental samples contaminated with CYP1A-inducing compounds.

Section.Description: This section summarizes the environmental fate/exposure of this chemical, including the natural and artificial sources of the chemical as a pollutant, its environmental fate, biodegradation, abiotic degradation, bioconcentration, etc.

StringWithMarkup.String: Perylene occurs ubiquitously as a product of incomplete combustion. Perylene has been identified in mainstream cigarette smoke and sidestream cigarette smoke, emissions from burning coal, fresh and used motor oils and in gasolines. Perylene occurs in charcoal-broiled steaks, ribs, chicken and their atmospheric emissions. Exhaust from gasoline, diesel and jet fuel engines contains perylene. Perylene is released in flue gas emissions from municipal waste incineration. Perylene occurs as a natural component of fossil fuels and may be released to the environment from volcanoes and forest fires. There is no commercial production or known use for perylene. If released to air, an extrapolated super-cooled vapor pressure of 5.0X10-10 mm Hg at 25 °C indicates perylene will exist primarily in the particulate phase in the atmosphere. However, a small percentage will exist is the vapor phase. Vapor-phase perylene will be degraded in the atmosphere by reaction with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals; the half-life for this reaction in air is estimated to be 7.7 hours. Particulate-phase perylene will be removed from the atmosphere by wet and dry deposition. Perylene absorbs strongly at wavelengths >290 nm and, therefore, is expected to be susceptible to direct photolysis by sunlight. If released to soil, perylene is expected to have no mobility based upon a mean Koc of 6.9X10+6. Volatilization from moist soil surfaces is not expected to be an important fate process based upon an estimated Henry's Law constant of 4.2X10-7 atm-cu m/mole. Perylene is not expected to volatilize from dry soil surfaces based upon its vapor pressure. Soil degradation studies have observed slow degradation of perylene. After 287 days of incubation, only 22.0-42.1% of initial 5-7 ring PAHs (including perylene) disappeared from three soils. The photolysis of perylene sorbed to the surface of spruce needles from a tree has an observed half-life of 21 hours under sunlight irradiation. If released into water, perylene is expected to adsorb to suspended solids and sediment based upon the Koc. Biodegradation of perylene reached 3-26% after 28 days of incubation in fresh and marine water-sediment degradation tests. Volatilization from water surfaces is not expected to be an important fate process based upon this compound's estimated Henry's Law constant. An estimated BCF of 6,700 suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is very high, provided the compound is not metabolized by the organism. However, it may not bioconcentrate in aquatic organisms which contain microsomal oxidase, such as fish, as this enzyme enables the rapid metabolism of certain polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons. A measured fish biotransformation half-life of 0.87 days has been reported for perylene. The bioaccumulation factor of perylene in golden ide fish (Leuciscus idus melanotus) was determined to be <10 after 3 days. Hydrolysis is not expected to be an important environmental fate process since this compound lacks functional groups that hydrolyze under environmental conditions. Occupational exposure to perylene may occur through inhalation and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where perylene is produced or used. Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be exposed to perylene via inhalation of ambient air, inhalation of tobacco smoke, ingestion of food and drinking water, and dermal contact with consumer products containing perylene. (SRC)

StringWithMarkup.String: TERRESTRIAL FATE: Based on a classification scheme(1), a mean Koc of 6.9X10+6 determined in 16 historically contaminated sediments(2) indicate that perylene is expected to be immobile in soil(SRC). Volatilization of perylene from moist soil surfaces is not expected to be an important fate process(SRC) given an estimated Henry's Law constant of 4.2X10-7 atm-cu m/mole(SRC), derived from its extrapolated vapor pressure, 5X10-10 mm Hg at 25 °C(3), and water solubility, 0.0004 mg/L(4). Perylene is not expected to volatilize from dry soil surfaces(SRC) based upon its extrapolated vapor pressure(3). PAHs with four or more rings, such as perylene, do not biodegrade readily(5) and are expected to be resistant to biodegradation(6). Soil degradation studies have observed slow degradation of perylene(7-11). For example, after 287 days of incubation, 22.0-42.1% of initial 5-7 ring PAHs (including perylene) disappeared from three non-sterilized soils(10). Bioremediation studies in field soil plots found that five and six rings PAHS, including perylene, had <10% removal after 1 year of bioremediation(11). The photolysis of perylene sorbed to the surface of spruce needles, (Picea Abies), follows first-order kinetics with a half-life of 21 hours under sunlight irradiation(12).

StringWithMarkup.String: AQUATIC FATE: Based on a classification scheme(1), a mean Koc of 6.9X10+6 determined in 16 historically contaminated sediments(2), indicates that perylene is expected to adsorb to suspended solids and sediment(SRC). Volatilization from water surfaces is not expected(3) based upon an estimated Henry's Law constant of 4.2X10-7 atm-cu m/mole(SRC), derived from its vapor pressure, 5X10-10 mm Hg(4), and water solubility, 0.0004 mg/L(5). According to a classification scheme(6), an estimated BCF of 6,700(SRC), from its log Kow of 6.30(7) and a regression-derived equation(8), suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is very high(SRC), provided the compound is not metabolized by the organism(SRC). However, perylene may not bioconcentrate in aquatic organisms which contain microsomal oxidase, such as fish, as this enzyme enables the rapid metabolism of certain polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons(9). A measured fish biotransformation half-life of 0.87 days has been reported for perylene(10). The bioaccumulation factor of perylene in golden ide fish (Leuciscus idus melanotus) was determined to be <10 after 3 days(11). PAHs with four or more rings, such as perylene, do not biodegrade readily(12) and are expected to be resistant to biodegradation(13). Biodegradation of perylene reached 3-26% after 28 days of incubation in fresh and marine water-sediment degradation tests(14). Hydrolysis is not expected to be an important environmental fate process since this compound lacks functional groups that hydrolyze under environmental conditions(3).

Reference: (1) Bidleman TF; Environ Sci Technol 22: 361-367 (1988)
(2) Goldfarb JL, Suuberg EM; J Chem Eng Data 53: 670-676 (2008)
(3) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.11. Nov, 2012. Available from, as of Nov 16, 2016: https://www2.epa.gov/tsca-screening-tools
(4) Perez S et al; Environ Sci Technol 37: 3794-3802 (2003)

(5) IARC Monographs on the Evaluation of the Carcinogenic Risk of Chemicals to Man. Polynuclear Aromatic Hydrocarbons Part I Chem and Environ Data. Vol 32: 411-418 (1983). Available from, as of Nov 17, 2016: https://monographs.iarc.fr/ENG/Classification/index.php
(6) Joblin C et al; J Chemical Physics 110: 7287-7297 (1999)
(7) Behymer TD, Hites RA; pp. 65-75 in Polynuclear Aromatic Hydrocarbons: Chemistry, Characterization and Carcinogenesis. 9th Inter Symp. Cook M, Dennis AJ, eds. Columbus,OH: Batelle (1986)

StringWithMarkup.String: ATMOSPHERIC FATE: According to a model of gas/particle partitioning of semivolatile organic compounds in the atmosphere(1), perylene, which has an extrapolated vapor pressure of 5.0X10-10 mm Hg at 25 °C(2), is expected to exist primarily in the particulate phase in the ambient atmosphere. Based on an estimated super-cooled vapor pressure of 1.5X10-7 mm Hg at 25 °C(3), a small percentage of perylene is expected to exist in the vapor phase in the ambient atmosphere(1). Ambient monitoring studies have detected perylene in both the particulate and vapor phases(4). Vapor-phase perylene is degraded in the atmosphere by reaction with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals(SRC); the half-life for this reaction in air is estimated to be 7.7 hours(SRC), calculated from its rate constant of 5.0X10-11 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(SRC) that was derived using a structure estimation method(3). Particulate-phase perylene may be removed from the air by wet and dry deposition(SRC). Perylene absorbs strongly at wavelengths >290 nm(5,6) and, therefore, is expected to be susceptible to direct photolysis by sunlight(SRC). The photolytic half-life of perylene adsorbed to silica, alumina, fly ash, and carbon black substrates were measured as 3.9, 1.2, 33, and 865 hours, respectively, following irradiation with a 400 watt mercury lamp(7).

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental biodegradation for this compound. Biodegradation is the breakdown of organic matter by microorganisms, such as bacteria and fungi.  An important measure of biodegradability of wastewater is the biochemical oxygen demand (BOD), which is the amount of dissolved oxygen (DO) needed (i.e. demanded) by aerobic biological organisms to break down organic material present in a given water sample at certain temperature over a specific time period.

Reference: (1) Walker JD, Colwell RR; Can J Microbiol 21: 305-13 (1975)
(2) Bossert ID et al; Appl Environ Microbiol 47: 763-7 (1984)
(3) Figge K et al; Regul Toxicol Pharmacol 3: 199-215 (1983)
(4) Freitag D et al; Chemosphere 14: 1589-1616 (1985)
(5) Verschueren K; Handbook of Environmental Data on Organic Chemicals. Volumes 1-2. 4th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, NY, pp. 1752-1754 (2001)
(6) Gramss G et al; Biodegradation 10: 51-62 (1999)
(7) Hawthorne SB, Grabanski CB; Environ Sci Technol 34: 4103-4110 (2000)

StringWithMarkup.String: AEROBIC: In a freshwater sediment sample taken from Colgate Creek, Maryland, 20-26% perylene was utilized by bacteria after 28 days(1); in a marine-water sediment sample taken from Eastern Bay, Maryland, 3-10% perylene was utilized by bacteria after 28 days(1). After 1,280 days, 59.5% of an initial concentration of perylene (3.1 ug/g) remained in a soil treated with oil sludge at a concentration of 28.0 ug/g(2). Perylene was 0.02% degraded in soil after 30 days(3). Perylene, at a concentration of 0.05 ppm in the presence of 0.05 mg/L activated sludge, produced <0.1 percent carbon dioxide in 5 days(4). No biodegradation of perylene was observed within 16 months in sandy loam soil in the dark at 20 °C(5). After 287 days of incubation, 22.0-42.1% of initial 5-7 ring PAHs (including perylene) disappeared from three non-sterilized soils(6). Bioremediation studies in field soil plots found that five and six rings PAHS, including perylene, had <10% removal after 1 year of bioremediation(7).

Reference: (1) ATSDR; Toxicological Profile for Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons. Atlanta, GA: Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry, US Public Health Service (1995). Available from, as of Sept 8, 2016: https://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxprofiles/index.asp
(2) Callahan MA et al; Water-Related Fate of 129 Priority Pollutants Vol II Chap 96. Washington,DC: USEPA-440/4-79-029B (1979)
(3) Boethling RS et al; Environ Sci Technol 28: 459-65 (1994)

StringWithMarkup.String: In general, polynuclear aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) with five or more benzene rings may not biodegrade readily(2). Dibenzo(a,h)pyrene contains six benzene rings. In one biodegradation study, the half-life for the largest PAH studied, benzo(a)pyrene, was 875 days in petroleum-contaminated sediment; rates in pristine sediment were 10 to 400 times slower(2). PAHs with four or more rings, such as perylene, are expected to be resistant to biodegradation(3).

Section.Description: Abiotic degradation is a process by which a chemical substance is broken down into smaller molecules by non-biotic means (e.g., hydrolysis, photolysis, and oxidation).

Reference: (1) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.11. Nov, 2012. Available from, as of Nov 16, 2016: https://www2.epa.gov/tsca-screening-tools
(2) Lyman WJ et al; Handbook of Chemical Property Estimation Methods. Washington, DC: Amer Chem Soc p. 7-4, 7-5 (1990)

(3) IARC Monographs on the Evaluation of the Carcinogenic Risk of Chemicals to Man. Polynuclear Aromatic Hydrocarbons Part I Chem and Environ Data. Vol 32: 411-418 (1983). Available from, as of Nov 17, 2016: https://monographs.iarc.fr/ENG/Classification/index.php

StringWithMarkup.String: The rate constant for the vapor-phase reaction of perylene with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals has been estimated as 5.0X10-11 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(SRC) using a structure estimation method(1). This rate constant corresponds to an atmospheric half-life of about 7.7 hours at an atmospheric concentration of 5X10+5 hydroxyl radicals per cu cm(1). Perylene is not expected to undergo hydrolysis in the environment due to the lack of functional groups that hydrolyze under environmental conditions(2). Perylene absorbs strongly at wavelengths >290 nm(3,4) and, therefore, is expected to be susceptible to direct photolysis by sunlight(SRC). Perylene, irradiated with light at wavelengths greater than 290 nm, was found to be 41.3 percent degraded after 17 hours(5). The photolytic half-life of perylene adsorbed to silica, alumina, fly ash, and carbon black substrates were measured as 3.9, 1.2, 33, and 865 hours, respectively, following irradiation with a 400 watt mercury lamp(6). The photolysis of perylene sorbed to the surface of spruce needles, (Picea Abies), follows first-order kinetics with a half-life of 21 hours under sunlight irradiation(7).

Reference: (1) Cope VW, Kalkwarf R; Environ Sci Technol 21: 643-48 (1987)
(2) Verschueren K; Handbook of Environmental Data on Organic Chemicals. 3rd ed. New York, NY: Van Nostrand Reinhold p. 1502 (1996)

(3) IARC Monographs on the Evaluation of the Carcinogenic Risk of Chemicals to Man. Polynuclear Aromatic Hydrocarbons Part I Chem and Environ Data. Vol 32: 411-418 (1983). Available from, as of Nov 17, 2016: https://monographs.iarc.fr/ENG/Classification/index.php
(4) Pitts JNJR et al; Environ Sci Technol 19: 1115-21 (1985)

StringWithMarkup.String: The ozonation rate constant for perylene on glass surfaces in the dark was determined to be 3.9X10-5 m/sec and <4.7X10-5 m/sec in the light(1). An 11% loss of perylene was observed within 16 months in sandy loam soil in the dark at 20 °C under abiotic conditions(2). Perylene has been found to be photo-oxidizable in the presence of acids(3). The reaction of perylene with dinitrogen pentoxide in an all-Teflon chamber yielded trace amounts of nitro derivatives after 30 min(4).

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental bioconcentration for this compound.  Bioconcentration is the accumulation of a chemical in or on an organism when the source of chemical is solely water. Bioconcentration is a term that was created for use in the field of aquatic toxicology. Bioconcentration can also be defined as the process by which a chemical concentration in an aquatic organism exceeds that in water as a result of exposure to a waterborne chemical.

Reference: (1) Andersson JT, Schrader W; Anal Chem 71: 3610-3614 (1999)
(2) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.11. Nov, 2012. Available from, as of Nov 16, 2016: https://www2.epa.gov/tsca-screening-tools
(3) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)
(4) Santodonato J et al; in Health and Ecological Assessment of Polynuclear Aromatic Hydrocarbons; Lee SD, Grant L eds., Park Forest South IL: Pathotox Publ (1981)
(5) Arnot JA et el; Environ Toxicol Chem 27: 2263-2270 (2008)
(6) Freitag D et al; Chemosphere 14: 1589-1616 (1985)
(7) Harkey GA et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 14: 1551-60 (1995)
(8) Hawker DW, Connell DW; Ecotox Environ Safety 11: 184-97 (1986)
(9) Meador JP et al; Rev Environ Contam Toxicol 143: 79-165 (1995)
(10) Verschueren K; Handbook of Environmental Data on Organic Chemicals. Volumes 1-2. 4th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, NY, pp. 1752-1754 (2001)

StringWithMarkup.String: An estimated BCF of 6700 was calculated in fish for perylene(SRC), using a log Kow of 6.30(1) and a regression-derived equation(2). According to a classification scheme(3), this BCF suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is very high(SRC), provided the compound is not metabolized by the organism(SRC). However, perylene may not bioconcentrate in aquatic organisms which contain microsomal oxidase, such as fish, as this enzyme enables the rapid metabolism of certain polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons(4). A measured fish biotransformation half-life of 0.87 days has been reported for perylene(5). The bioaccumulation factor of perylene in golden ide fish (Leuciscus idus melanotus) was determined to be <10 after 3 days, the bioaccumulation factor of perylene in algae (Chlorella fusca) was determined to be 2,010 after 1 day, and the bioaccumulation factor of perylene in activated sludge was determined to be 22,900 after 5 days(6). Perylene was shown to bioaccumulate in worms exposed to contaminated sediment over a 4 week incubation period, reaching a max concentration of 227 ng/g(7). The bioconcentration factor for perylene in the Daphnid Pulex was determined to be 7,079(8). The half-life of perylene in rainbow trout, clams, mussels, oysters, and shrimp averaged 2, 4.3-26.2, 6.3-13.3, 9.2 and 1.2 days, respectively(9). The bioconcentration factor of perylene in polychaete worms was determined to be 16 (polychaeta dry wt/sediments dry wt) in Prionospio cirrifera/ Spiochaetpoterus costarum and 0.4 (polychaeta dry wt/sediments dry wt) in Capitella capitata(10).

Section.Description: Sorption to soils and sediments is an important factor on the transport and fate of organic contaminants in the environment.  The soil/water adsorption coefficient, also known as solid-water distribution coefficient (Kd), measures the amount of chemical substance adsorbed onto soil per amount of water.  Since adsorption occurs predominantly by partition into the soil organic matter, it is more useful to normalize the Kd value to the organic carbon content of a soil and express the distribution coefficient in Koc (organic carbon normalized distribution coefficient).  The greater the Kd (or Koc) value, the less likely a chemical will leach or contribute to runoff.  A very high value means it is strongly adsorbed onto soil and organic matter and does not move throughout the soil.

Reference: (1) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.11. Nov, 2012. Available from, as of Nov 16, 2016: https://www2.epa.gov/tsca-screening-tools
(2) Hawthorne SB et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 25: 2901-2911 (2006)
(3) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 23 (1983)

StringWithMarkup.String: Using a structure estimation method based on molecular connectivity indices(1), the Koc of perylene can be estimated to be 6.0X10+5(SRC). The Koc of perylene in 16 historically contaminated sediments ranged from 3.4X10+5 to 3.2X10+7 with a mean of 6.9X10+6(2). According to a classification scheme(3), these Koc values suggest that perylene is expected to be immobile in soil.

Section.Description: Volatilization of chemicals from water/soil is the transfer of the chemical as a gas through the water-air or soil-air interface under environmental conditions

(2) Yalkowsky SH et al; Handbook of Aqueous Solubility Data 2nd ed., Boca Raton, FL: CRC Press,  p. 1216 (2010)
(3) Lyman WJ et al; Handbook of Chemical Property Estimation Methods. Washington, DC: Amer Chem Soc pp. 15-1 to 15-29 (1990)

StringWithMarkup.String: The Henry's Law constant for perylene is estimated as 4.2X10-7 atm-cu m/mole(SRC) derived from its extrapolated vapor pressure, 5X10-10 mm Hg(1), and water solubility, 0.0004 mg/L(2). This Henry's Law constant indicates that perylene is expected to be essentially nonvolatile from water surfaces(3). Perylene's estimated Henry's Law constant indicates that volatilization from moist soil surfaces is not expected to occur(SRC). Perylene is not expected to volatilize from dry soil surfaces(SRC) based upon its vapor pressure(1).

Section.Description: Concentrations of this chemical in water in various stages of hydrologic cycle (e.g., drinking water, ground water, surface water, and rain/snow).

StringWithMarkup.String: GROUNDWATER: The concn of perylene in surface and groundwaters in the Thames River and in the United States ranged from 40-120 ng/L and <1-7 ng/L, respectively(1). Perylene has been found in subterranean water, 0.0-0.2 ng/L(2). Goundwater sampled from wells near gasoline stations of Rio de Janerio, Brazil during 2003 and 2004 detected perylene concentrations of <0.01 to 0.261 ug/L(3).

Reference: (1) Fatima AM; Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons. Org Micropollut Aquat Environ, 6th Proc Eur Symp, pp. 366-70 (1990)

StringWithMarkup.String: DRINKING WATER: Perylene was detected in drinking water of the Oporto, Portugal district with concentrations ranging from 0.3 to 7.3 ng/L(1). Perylene has been found in various tap waters at concentrations of 0.1-1.4 ng/L(2).

StringWithMarkup.String: SURFACE WATER: Water samples collected in 1992 at 9 sites along the San Jaoquin River, California were found to contain perylene concentrations ranging from <1.0 to 11 ng/L(1). The concentration of perylene in surface and groundwaters in the Thames River and in the United States ranged from 40-120 ng/L and <1-7 ng/L, respectively(2). Perylene has been found in various surface waters at concentrations ranging from 0-520 ng/L(3). Perylene concentrations ranged from 0 to <10 ng/L in six stations located in the Guanabara Bay Basin, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, sampled from September 2011 to August 2012(4). Sampling of water from the Coral Reef of southern Taiwan between 2006-2007 detected perylene in both the dissolved phase and in the particulate phase of the water(5).

Reference: (1) Dachs J et al; Environ Sci Technol 31: 682-88 (1997)
(2) Law RJ, Whinnett JA; Oceanol ACTA 16: 593-97 (1993)

StringWithMarkup.String: SEAWATER: Seawater samples collected in the western Mediterranean off the coast of Spain in 1993 contained perylene concentrations ranging from approximately 0.5-6 pg/L(1). Perylene was identified in seawater samples collected from June 1990 to July 1991 in the Dover Strait with concentrations ranging from <1 to 2.1 ng/L(2).

Reference: (1) Capel PD et al; Atmos Environ 28: 1139-45 (1994)
(2) Ligocki MP et al; Atmos Environ 19: 1619-26 (1985)
(3) Mazurek MA, Simoneit BRT; CRC Critical Review Environ Control Vol 16 pp. 16-7 (1986)

(5) Gouin T et al; Atmos Pollut Research 1: 9-15 (2010)

StringWithMarkup.String: RAIN/SNOW: The average concentration of perylene measured in the fog of Zurich, Switzerland was 0.75 ng/mL, with concentrations ranging from 0.00 to 2.0 ng/mL(1). Perylene was identified in rain samples collected in 1984 in Portland, OR as having an average concentration of 0.58 ng/L(2). Perylene has been detected in rain and snow samples from urban Moscow, USSR, and urban/rural Norway network, concentration not reported(3). Perylene has been found in various rain waters at concentrations of 0.00-1.0 ng/L(4). Snowdump sampled in Fairbanks, Alaska in 2009 contained a mean perylene concentration of 1890 ng/L(5).

Section.Description: Concentration of this compound in effluent.  Effluent is wastewater (treated or untreated) discharged into surface waters from a treatment plant, sewer, or industrial outfall.

StringWithMarkup.String: In an industrial wastewater survey in which samples collected between November 1, 1979 to November 1, 1981 which analyzed for organic pollutants other than Priority Pollutants, a perylene concentration of 143 ng/uL (extract) was identified from the timber product industry(1). The concentration of perylene in the sediment of a wastewater effluent channel from a coking plant was determined to be 3.8 ug/g dry weight(2). Leachate effluent from a municipal waste dump in Niterol City, Brazil during 1998-1999 sampling had perylene concentrations of 0.02-0.41 ug/L(3).

StringWithMarkup.String: The effluent from an Italian municipal solid waste incinerator contained a perylene concentration of 1015 ng/cu m(1). Perylene was identified as a stack emission and a component of fly ash from municipal waste incinerators(2). Perylene was identified as a stack emissions and in grate and fly ash from coal combustion(3). Refuse burning of plastics was found to emit perylene(4). Flue gas from a municipal waste incinerator had a perylene concentration of 0.268 ug/cu m(5).

StringWithMarkup.String: The concentration of perylene in turbine engine exhaust has been determined to range from 5.53 to 12.11 ng/cu m(1). Fine aerosol emission rates for perylene from non-catalyst automobiles, catalyst automobiles, and heavy-duty diesel trucks were determined to be 14.0, 0.60, and 1.0 ug/km, respectively(2). The exhaust emitted from passenger ferries operating in the Skagerak-Kattegatt-Oresund region of Norway was found to contain perylene concentrations ranging from <0.04 to <0.2 ug/cu nm(3). Outboard marine engines (2- and 4-stroke) were found to emit perylene in their exhaust(4). Emission measurements from a variety of military vehicles (gasoline, diesel, jet fuels) at Hill Air Force Base (Ogden, UT) in Nov 2000 detected many PAHs in exhausts, including perylene(5). The emission factor of perylene from light and heavy duty vehicles measured in a California tunnel was determined to be 0.80 ug/kg fuel burned(6).

StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENT: Surficial sediments from the Shatt Al-Arab River and the North-West Region of the Arabian Gulf collected from November 1979 to April 1980 were found to contain perylene concentrations ranging from 0.04 to 11.22 ng/g(1). Perylene was found in sediments collected at 10 sites in the Sudafjord, W Norway in concentrations ranging from 0.6 to 1757 ppb(2). Perylene was identified in sediment collected near various industrial emission sources on the Swedish Baltic Coast (concentrations not reported)(3). Marine sediment samples collected from the Baltic proper and from the Gulf in Finland were determined to have perylene concentrations of 50 and 65 ng/g, respectively(4). The concentration of perylene in 30 sediment samples collected at 15 different sites from the Gulf of Lion, France ranged from not detected to 264.3 ng/g(5). The average concentration of perylene in surface sediment samples taken from the Brisbane River Estuary, Australia from January-May 1986 was determined to range from 0.03 to 0.14 ug/g; the average perylene concentration range in particulates in water was determined to be 0.27-0.89 ug/g(6). Sediments collected in Tokyo Bay in July and Aug 1973 contained perylene at concentrations ranging from 0.006 to 0.305 mg/kg dry weight(7). Sediment samples (12) of various parts of Lake Lagoda, Russia collected in June 1993 were found to contain perylene ranging in concentration from 1.6 to 200 ng/g(8). The concentration of perylene in the sediment of an uncontrolled hazardous waste dump near the Nervion River, North Spain, was determined to range from 0.6 to 50 ug/g(9). Perylene, at levels of <0.10 ug/g, was one of many PAHs detected in 188 soil samples collected around the Tianjin area, China in the early 2000s(10). Sediments collected from the Pearl River Estuary and the North South China Sea in July 2002 contained perylene concentrations of 25-200 ng/g(10). Sediment cores (45 cm in depth) collected from remote mountain lake in central Chile had perylene concentrations ranging from about 300 to 5000 ng/g dry wt(11).

Reference: (1) Fabacher DL et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 7: 529-43 (1988)
(2) Harkey GA et al; Chemosphere 28: 583-96 (1994)
(3) Malins DC et al; Carcinogenesis 6: 1463-69 (1985)
(4) Brooks JM et al; Environ Sci Technol 24: 1079-85 (1990)
(5) Ko FC et al; Chemosphere 66: 277-285 (2007)

StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENT: Perylene concentrations of 0.092 to 5.90 ug/g dry wt were detected in sediments from 5 rivers that feed the Great Lakes(1). Perylene concentration levels ranged from 196.0 to 620.7 ng/g in sediment cores obtained from Lake George, MI (at a 16 m depth) in October 1993(2). The concentration of perylene in sediment samples collected from Eagle Harbor and President Point, WA in 1983 ranged from 17 to 500 ng/g(3). Bed sediments collected in 1993 at 16 sites along the Lauritzen Canal and Richmond Harbor, California were found to contain perylene concentrations ranging from 88 to 510 ng/g(3). Bottom sediments collected in the vicinity of a multi-well platform offshore of Matagorda, TX from May 1982 to November 1985 had an average perylene concentration of 13.6 ppb(4). Surface sediments collected at four sites of the Susquehanna River in 2000 had average perylene concentrations ranging from 23.70 to 424.90 ng/g dry wt(5).

Reference: (1) Pereira WE et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 15: 172-80 (1996)

StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENT: Bed sediments collected in 1992 at 9 sites along the San Jaoquin River, California were found to contain perylene concentrations ranging from 0.5 to 12 ng/L(1). The concentration of perylene in sediment cores collected from 17 locations on the Washington, USA continental shelf and slope was determined to range from 0.3 to 3.6 ug/g(2). Perylene was detected in sediments from remote Adirondack lakes in NY, ppm dry wt (depth, cm): Sagamore Lake, 1600 (0 to 8), 2100 (8 to 12), 210 to 5000(12 to 85); Woods Lake, 280 (0 to 4), 490 (4 to 8), 250 (8 to 11), 120 to 950 (12 to 84)(3). Collectively, perylene has been found in dried sediment from many lakes at concentrations ranging from 4-680 ug/kg(4).

Reference: (1) Blumer M et al; Environ Sci Technol 11: 1082-84 (1977)
(2) Pichler M et al; Environ Sci Pollut Res 3: 24-31 (1996)

StringWithMarkup.String: SOIL: Perylene was detected in the soils of a Swiss mountain valley (concentration not reported)(1). Perylene was identified, not quantified in soil samples from German forests(2). Samples of surface soil colleted from urban areas of Japan were found to contain a perylene concentrations ranging from <2 to 38 ug/kg(3). Perylene was identified in 30 soil samples collected from Nova Scotia in October 1976 at concentrations ranging from 0.1 to 68 ppb(4). Perylene was measured in the soil at an urban roadside in Australia at a concentration of 147 ng/g(5). A sample of sandy loam soil contaminated 40 years previously was collected at a site in southern New Jersey and was found to contain 7.4 ug/g perylene(6). Perylene, at levels of <0.10 ug/g, was one of many PAHs detected in 188 soil samples collected around the Tianjin area, China in the early 2000s(7). Sampling of Japanese padd soil between 1959-2002 found a mean and median perylene concentration of 8.0 an 4.3 ug/kg dry wt respectively(8).

StringWithMarkup.String: URBAN/SUBURBAN: During a high nitrogen oxide episode in Los Angeles, CA in Feb 1986, a perylene concentration of 0.47-0.5 ng/cu m was measured during daylight and a perylene concentration of 0.18-0.2 ng/cu m was measured at night-time(1). Airborne monitoring of air samples from four NJ cities (Newark, Elizabeth, Camden, Ringwood) during the summers and winters from 1981 to 1983 found mean perylene concentrations of 0.03-0.10 ng/cu m(2). Sampling at sites near the US-Mexico border during 1998-1999 detected perylene concentrations of 0.04-0.8 ng/cu m in the PM10 particulates(3).

StringWithMarkup.String: URBAN/SUBURBAN: Perylene was identified in particulate phase ambient air at two sites with different traffic conditions in Tokyo, Japan from June 1993 to May 1994 with concentrations ranging from not detected to 1.04 ng/cu-m near the highway Loop 7 and not detected to 0.45 ng/cu-m at the National Garden(1). The winter, spring, summer and fall concentration of perylene in the ambient air of Hoyanger, Mosjoen, Ovre Ardal and Ardalstangen, Norway were 4.9, 2, 3.1 and 5.3; 1.7, 4.6, 4.9 and 1.5; 8.3, 2.5, 0.5 and 4.3; and 5.1, 0.9, 1.3 and 2 ng/cu m(2). The average concentration of perylene in the urban atmospheric particulate matter in Tokyo, Japan was determined to be 7.8 ug/g of particulates(3). The atmospheric perylene concentration at a roadside in Australia was measured as 0.22 ng/cu-m(4). Aerosol samples collected at six sites in Hong Kong during the winter months of 1993 were found to contain perylene concentrations ranging from 24 to 2060 pg/cu m(5). The seasonal concentration of perylene in the atmosphere of Barcelona, Spain was determined to be 2.65, not detected, 0.42, and 0.61 ng/cu m in spring, summer, fall, and winter, respectively(6). Airborne particulate matter collected from nine places in the Upper Silesia Region of Poland during the winter of 1988/1989 and summer of 1989 had a perylene concentration range of 3.6 to 12.5 ng/cu m in the winter and 0.9 to 22.6 ng/cu m in the summer(7). Perylene concentrations in airborne particles sampled at four sites in an urban and industrialized area in the Netherlands ranged from 0.08 to 127.67 ng/cu m(8). Air sampling during March 2003 in Xigu District, Lanzhou, China detected a perylene concentration of 203 ng/cu m(9). Perylene was detected in ambient particulate matter collected at several areas in Stockholm, Sweden between 2003-2006 at levels of 10-100 pg/cu m(10).

Reference: (1) Gustafson P et al; Environ Sci Technol 42: 5074-5080 (2008)

StringWithMarkup.String: INDOOR AIR: Monitoring of indoor air in wood-burning Swedish homes in 2003 found a perylene range of limit of quantification (not reported) to 0.06 ng/cu m(1).

Reference: (1) Fellin P et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 15: 253-61 (1996)
(2) Del Vento S, Dachs J; Environ Sci Technol 41: 5608-5613 (2007)

StringWithMarkup.String: RURAL/REMOTE: Perylene was detected in the atmosphere of a workstation in the Arctic on Ellesmere Island, Canada as having average concentrations from May-September of 0.2 pg/cu m and 18.5 pg/cu m from October-April(1). Perylene was detected in atmospheric particulate matter collected over northeast tropical and subtropic areas of the Atlantic ocean in 2003(2); the deposition flux to the surface was estimated to be 0.00-0.37 ng/sq m/day(2).

Reference: (1) de Raat WK, de Meijere FA; Sci Tot Environ 103: 1-17 (1991)

StringWithMarkup.String: SOURCE DOMINATED: The average perylene concentration in ambient airborne particles from local traffic in Delft, The Netherlands was determined to be 11.5 ng/100 cu m(1). Air particulate matter collected in Bahrain from July 1991 to August 1991 during the burning of the oil fields in Kuwait were found to contain perylene concentrations ranging from <0.05 to 0.19 ng/cu-m(2). The concentration of perylene measured in underground Canadian mines in the vicinity of diesel vehicles was determined to range from 0.1 to 1.1 ng/cu m(3). The concentration of perylene in air samples collected from the Baltimore Harbor Tunnel in Baltimore, MD on three occasions in 1985 and 1986 was determined to average 8.0 ng/cu-m(4). Perylene was identified but not quantified in airborne particulate matter near a Horizontal Stud Soderberg plant in Quebec, Canada over a three month period during the Fall of 1992(5). Perylene was identified in a Soderberg, Norway anode plant and vertical pin plant; perylene particulate levels in the atmosphere ranged from 0.69 to 8.5 ug/cu-m in the anode plant and 0.56 to 1.8 ug/cu-m at the pin plant(6). The level of perylene in charcoal smoke and in charcoal and meat smoke from charcoal grilling was determined to be <0.1 ug/kg for both(7). The concentration of perylene in mesquite smoke and hickory smoke was determined to be 14 ug/kg and 4 ug/kg, respectively(8).

StringWithMarkup.String: Perylene has been identified in many food sources (ug/kg): kippered cod, 0.4; smoked whiting, 0.7; canned smoked fish, 1.0; canned smoked oysters, 20.0; charcoal-broiled porterhouse steak, 2.0; charcoal-broiled barbecued chicken, 2.0; fresh oysters, 0.7-1.0; very dark coffee, 0.8; coffee soots, 280-660; Japanese horse mackerel, trace-0.2; charcoal-broiled steaks, 3.5; and charcoal-broiled barbecued ribs, 42(1). Perylene was found in fermented, smoked, and dried mutton sausages in concentrations ranging from not detected to 0.15 ppb; the concentration of perylene in cook and smoked bologna sausages ranged from not detected to 0.07 ppb(2). Perylene was found in the following Finnish fats (ug/kg): butter (0.02), cooking margarines (0.57), table margarines (0.48), cold pressed sunflower oil (0.08), corn oil (0.09), cold pressed corn oil (0.58), rapeseed oil (0.92), soybean oil (0.55), and crude coconut oil (5.9)(3). The concentration of perylene in lettuce grown at varying distances from a highway in Sweden was determined to range from not detected to 0.1 ug/kg fresh weight(4).

Reference: (1) Lawrence JF, Weber DF; J Agric Food Chem 32: 794-97 (1984)
(2) Maga J; J Agric Food Chem 34: 249-51 (1986)

StringWithMarkup.String: The concentration of perylene in barley malt, cooking oil, milled wheat, and breakfast cereals was determined to range from 0.1-0.4 ug/kg, 0.1-0.2 ug/kg, 0.1-0.6 ug/kg, and 0.1-1.5 ug/k, respectively(1). The concentration of perylene in a grilled mesquite wood beef patty 70% lean was determined to be 3 ug/kg(2). The fine aerosol emission rate for perylene from a charbroiled hamburger (regular) was determined to be 0.03 mg/kg(3). The concentration of perylene in lettuce, rye, and soybean grown in different (unspecified) environments was determined to be 0.4, 0.25, 0.9, and 0.3 ug/kg, respectively(4). The concentration of perylene in leaf lettuce was determined to range from not detected to 0.75 ug/kg(5). Perylene concentrations of 3.89-20.72 ug/kg were detected in Spanish olive pomace oil(6).

StringWithMarkup.String: Perylene concentrations in traditionally preserved Nigerian freshwater fish species Clarias lazera, Sarotherodon niloticus, Sarotherodon galileus, Tilapia zilli and Hemichromis fasciatus were determined to range from 0.01 to 19.21 ng/g(1). Perylene was found in mussels collected at 10 sites in the Sudafjord, W Norway in concentrations ranging from 35 to 3976 ppb(2). The concentration level of perylene in mussels (Perna canaliculus) collected from the island of Tenerife ranged from not detected to 339 ng/g(3). The average concentration of perylene in Diporeia after 28 days ranged from 373-496 nmol/g(4). Perylene was identified in Cipangopaludina chinensis (gastropod) soft tissue samples collected from Hamilton Bay, Lake Ontario as having a concentration of 25.90 ug/kg(5). Perylene concentrations of 0.065-2.4 ng/g wet weight were detected in oysters collected from 18 stations in the Yatsushiro Sea, Japan in 2010(6). Perylenen was detected (concentrations not reported) in mussels (Mytilus edulis chilensis) collected from 12 coastal locations in Ushuaia Bay, Argentina, and the surrounding area in October 1999 and again in October 2003(7).

StringWithMarkup.String: The concentration of perylene in mussels (Elliptio complanata) after 3 weeks exposure in 1985 in the St. Mary's River, Michigan/Canada was determined to range from 0.4 to 21 ug/kg(1). The concentration of perylene in the stomach organisms of English sole (Parophrys vetulus) collected from Eagle Harbor and President Point, WA in 1983 was determined to range from 15 to 650 ng/g(2). Perylene was detected in composites of stomach organisms from juvenile chinook salmon captured from the Duwamish Waterway, WA in 6/86 and the Nisqually River, WA in 6/87 at average concentrations of 1.2 and <0.075 ug/g dry weight, respectively(3). Perylene concentrations identified in specimens of the marine winkle Osilinus attratus collected off the coast of Tenerife, near northern Africa, ranged from 13.7 to 42.2 ng/g(4). The concentration of perylene measured in clams, Tridacna maxima, collected from sites along the Great Barrier Reef, Australia, from December 1980 to August 1982 ranged from <0.04 to 0.20 ug/kg wet wt(5). Lake trout caught from Lakes Michigan and Superior in 1990-1991 had average perylene concentrations of below detection limits and 0.15 ng/g wet weight respectively(6); after smoke cooking, respective perylene levels were 1.84 and 0.73 ng/g(6).

StringWithMarkup.String: The concentration of perylene in seston, mussel (Mytilus edulis) soft parts, and common eider duck (Somateria mollissima) gallbladders collected, from the early summer to early autumn of 1985 and 1986 in the Baltic Sea, was determined to be 31, 4.3, and <0.1 ng/g dry wt, respectively(1). The perylene concentration found along the northern side of Kessels Road, Brisbane, Queensland, Australia was measured to be 1, 1, 2, and 4 ng/g in a beetle (Laxta granicollis), a millipede, a beetle (Platyzosteria nitida), and an earthworm, respectively(2).

StringWithMarkup.String: The concentration of perylene in mineral oil was determined to be 1.02 ug/10 g(1). Perylene has been found in the following: lubricating oils, 0.007-0.224 mg/kg; various fresh and used motor oils, 0.04-10.0 mg/kg; gasolines, 0.01-0.16 mg/kg(2). The concentration of perylene in lubricating oil from three different vehicles fueled with gasoline, diesel, gas was determined to be 6.8, 0.26, and 4.4 ppm, respectively(3). Perylene was identified in crude oil and purified oil(4). The concentration ranges of perylene in new motor oil, used motor oil from petrol vehicles, used motor oil from diesel vehicles, used motor oil from diesel lorries, and used motor oil from diesel buses was determined to be 0.007-0.224, 1.9-10.0, 0.4-2.7, 0.11-0.35, and 0.04-0.29 ug/g, respectively(5). The perylene concentration of a base diesel fuel was 0.03-0.05 mg/L(6).

StringWithMarkup.String: Perylene was found in high-temperature coal tar at a level of 0.25%(1). Perylene has been detected in emissions of burnt coal (0.09-1.9 mg/kg)(2). The concentration of perylene in smoke samples taken from intentionally burned Alberta Sweet Crude oil ranged from 18-52 ug/g(3). Open burning of cereal grains produced perylene concentrations ranging from 0.74 to 4158 ug/kg(4). Perylene emission factors from combustion of six woods grown in the northeastern US was found to be 0.008-0.024 mg/g(5). Combustion of scrap tires emitted perylene levels 210 mg/kg scrap tire(6). A laboratory batch combustion study styrene found a maximum perylene emission factor of nearly 160 ug/g(7). Open burning of various types of coal was found to have a perylene emission factor in the smoke of 0.08 to 40 mg/kg of coal burned(8).

The emission rate of perylene from the burning of two incense samples was 2.621-3.11 ng/minute(2).

StringWithMarkup.String: Perylene was found on road dust particles at a concentration of 0.48 ug/g of particle sample(1). Deposited road particles collected from 13 heavily traveled roadways in an urban area near Lake Biwa, Japan in 1999 had perylene concentrations of <0.01 to 0.035 ug/g dry wt(2). Street dust collected in Dalian, Liaining Province, China in July 2007 contained perylene (concentration not reported)(3).

StringWithMarkup.String: NIOSH (NOES Survey 1981-1983) has statistically estimated that 253 workers (34 of these are female) are potentially exposed to perylene in the US(1). Occupational exposure to perylene may occur through inhalation and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where perylene is produced or used. Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be exposed to perylene via inhalation of ambient air, inhalation of tobacco smoke, ingestion of food and drinking water, and dermal contact with consumer products containing perylene(SRC). Human exposure to perylene occurs primarily through the smoking of tobacco, inhalation of polluted air and by ingestion of food and drinking water contaminated with combustion products(2). In one study, workers were exposed to 0.04 to 1.24 ng/cu m perylene at different work sites of a silicon carbide process plant in Switzerland(3).

StringWithMarkup.String: The average daily intake of perylene in ambient air samples collected between November 1981 and August 1982 from Osaka, Japan was determined to be 0.76 ng/day/man(1).

These references have been ranked automatically by an algorithm which calculates the relevance for each substance in a Springer Nature document. It is based on: (1) the TF-IDF, adapted to chemical structures, (2) location information in the text (e.g. title, abstract, keywords), and (3) the document size.  Springer Nature aims to provide only highly qualitative and relevant content but references of lower relevance aren't withheld as they might contain also very useful information.

Reference.Description: The International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) is the specialized cancer agency of the World Health Organization. The objective of the IARC is to promote international collaboration in cancer research.

Reference.Name: EPA SRS List Classification
Reference.Description: Substance Registry Services (SRS) is the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) central system for information about substances that are tracked or regulated by EPA or other sources. It is a resource for basic information about chemicals, biological organisms, and other substances of interest to EPA and its state and tribal partners. SRS makes it possible to identify which EPA data systems, environmental statutes, or other sources have information about a substance and which synonym is used by that system or statute.

Reference.Name: EPA TSCA Classification
Reference.Description:
EPA Chemicals under the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) collection contains information on chemicals and their regulation under TSCA. The chemical classification tree is created based on the TSCA substance regulatory flag, UVCB, and commercial activity status.

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.

Reference.Name: SID 403030615
Reference.Description: The PATENTSCOPE database from WIPO includes patent and chemical structure search (with a free account) that gives access to millions of patent documents. The World Intellectual Property Organisation (WIPO) is a specialized United Nations (UN) agency headquartered in Geneva (Switzerland). Our mission is to lead the development of a balanced and effective international Intellectual Property (IP) system that enables innovation and creativity for the benefit of all. We help governments, businesses and society realize the benefits of Intellectual Property and are notably a world reference source for IP information.
